column1: '''Angus McIntosh''' ([[10 January]] [[1914]] - [[26 October]] [[2005]]) was a Scottish linguist and medievalist.<ref name="Obit">{{webcite|author=Professor Heinz Giegerich|articleurl=http://www.inf.ed.ac.uk/events/amcintosh.html|articlename=Obituary: Professor Angus McIntosh|dated=|website=[http://www.ed.ac.uk/ University of Edinburgh]|accessed=16-12-2012}}</ref>
McIntosh was educated at Oriel College Oxford and graduated in 1934. He went on to a diploma in comparative philology at Merton College
column2: and became a student of [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]. McIntosh is said to:

column1: {{Blockquote|...one day to have thrashed JRR Tolkien at tennis
column2: confining him to his rooms with an ankle injury. Thus marooned
column4: Tolkien started sketching out ideas for The Hobbitt [sic] and The Lord of the Rings works for which Angus would cheerfully accept blame."|Heinz Giegerich: ''Angus McIntosh Obituary''<ref name="Obit"/>}}

column2: <ref>{{L|35|1}}</ref> McIntosh was enrolled in the British Amry to decrypt Enigma codes during World War II. At war's end
column3: he returned to a lectureship at Christ Church Oxford
column4: conducting seminars on [[Middle English]] with Tolkien
column7: McIntosh moved to the University of Edinburgh
column8: where Tolkien and his daughter [[Priscilla Tolkien|Priscilla]] were to visit him and his wife in July
